content.text: Assemble the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1
The two resistors are identical
A, B and C are crocodile clips. Connect C to the screw
Connect A to the wire at a distance \(p\) of approximately \(25\mathrm{cm}\) from the screw, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Close the switch
Position B on the other side of the screw so that the two voltmeter readings have **the same value** \(V.\)
The distance between the screw and B is \(q\), as shown in Fig. 1.2
Measure and record the distances \(p\) and \(q\). Record \(V.\)
Open the switch
Change \(p\) and repeat (a)(iii), (a)(iv), (a)(v) and (a)(vi) until you have six sets of values of \(p\), \(q\) and \(V\)
Record your results in a table
Include values of \(\frac{1}{p}\) and \(\frac{1}{q}\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{q}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{p}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =

where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants
Use your answers in **(c)**(iii) to determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\)
Give appropriate units
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit
You are provided with two joined springs and three joined springs. Using the **two** joined springs, set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1
Measure and record the height \(h_{1}\) of the bottom of the mass hanger above the bench, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Add the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass to the mass hanger. Measure and record the height \(h_{2}\) of the bottom of the mass hanger above the bench
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(h_{2}\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Calculate the spring constant \(k\) for the combination, using the expression
where \(m = 0.100 \text{kg}\) and \(g = 9.81 \text{N} \text{kg}^{-1}\)
Justify the number of significant figures you have given for your value of \(k\)
Use small pieces of adhesive tape to reduce movement at the joints between components, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Rotate the mass hanger and mass through one turn and release them
The masses make rotational oscillations, as shown in Fig. 2.3
Take measurements to find the period \(T\) of the rotational oscillations
Repeat (a)(ii), (a)(iii), (b)(i) and (c) using the three joined springs
Using your data, calculate two values of \(C\)
first value of \(C =\)
second value of \(C =\)
Explain whether your results in (e)(i) support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(T\) and \(k\) is
where \(C\) is a constant
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment, you will investigate the rotational oscillation of a combination of springs
